title: Why can't we look inside an exoplanet? - Quora

response.answer_text: Q: Why can't we look inside an exoplanet? A: In most of the cases, the reason is that we only know that they exist because how the planet influences other things, like its host star. In some cases where we can observe the planet directly, it’s because the surface is in the way. “But isn’t that the case of our planets? How can we know what they look inside?” I’m glad you asked. That’s because we don’t actually look inside with our eyes. Instead, we listen and we sense. We listen to quakes, we sense the force of gravity and we even smell and taste the molecules near them. And we look at the surface. Then we take all that data and our knowledge of how the universe behaves, and try to figure out what could give the results we see. That way, we get an understanding of the inside of a planet. We can¨t do that to exoplanets. If we see them at all, it is as a few pixels, not enough to get any clues from the processes inside. And they’re so far away that it would take hundreds of thousands, if not millions, of years using today’s rocket technology to send a space probe there to look, sense, listen and taste for us.

Q: Why can't we look inside an exoplanet? Because they are far away? And technically speaking, we can’t really much “look inside” even into our own planet. We can do measurements with instruments on the surface, and conclude a lot of things. Looking inside would only work if they’d consist 100% out of transparent material… which they don’t. The deepest hole ever drilled was a bit over 12 km, Earth’s diameter is 12.756 km, radius = >6000 km. So we have “looked into” at one place 1/500’s of the distance to the center.
